the centripetal acceleration
acceleration =   .........  \(\text{ms}^{-2}\)
For point X, determine:
State Lenz's law of electromagnetic induction
Show that the time taken for point X to complete one revolution is \(45 \text{ms}\)
Calculate the magnetic flux cut by spoke AX during one revolution of the wheel. Give a unit with your answer
magnetic flux =   .........  unit   .........
Determine the magnitude of the electromotive force (e.m.f.) induced across spoke AX
Use Lenz's law to explain whether the potential is higher at end A or end X of the spoke
There is a uniform magnetic field of flux density \(0.18 \text{T}\) into the plane of the page
A metal wheel consists of an axle A, eight spokes and a rim, as shown in Fig. 1.1
Point X is on the rim at the end of one of the spokes
The rim has a radius of \(0.85 \text{m}\)
The wheel is rotating clockwise with an angular speed of \(140 \text{rad} \text{s}^{-1}\)
Define gravitational field
calculate \(g\)
determine the gravitational potential energy \(E_{\mathrm{p}}\) of the probe
For the position of the probe where \(x = 1.47 \times 10^{11} \text{m}\):
Show that, for any particular value of \(x\), the numerical values of \(g\) and \(F\) are related by
where \(M\) is the mass of the Sun, \(L\) is the luminosity of the Sun and \(G\) is the gravitational constant
Fig. 2.1 shows the variation of \(g\) with \(F\)
Determine a value for the luminosity \(L\) of the Sun. Give a unit with your answer
Use your answer in (c)(ii) to determine the radius \(r\) of the Sun
The Sun may be considered as a uniform sphere with a mass of \(1.99 \times 10^{30} \text{kg}\) and a surface temperature of \(5780 \text{K}\)
A probe with a mass of \(2.63 \text{kg}\) moves in a straight line towards the Sun
When it is at a distance \(x\) from the centre of the Sun, the probe measures the gravitational field strength \(g\) due to the Sun and the radiant flux intensity \(F\) of radiation from the Sun
Define specific latent heat
Show that the magnitude of the work done on the substance when it vaporises is \(1.7 \text{kJ}\)
Use the information in **(b)**(i) to calculate the thermal energy \(Q\), in kJ, supplied to the substance to cause it to vaporise

parts.label: (iii)

content.text: Use your answer in **(b)**(ii) to determine a value for the specific latent heat of vaporisation \(L_{\mathrm{v}}\), in \(\mathrm{kJ} \mathrm{kg}^{-1}\), of the substance

content.text: A dish containing \(7.2 \times 10^{-5} \text{m}^3\) of a substance rests on a laboratory bench. The substance is initially a liquid of density \(710 \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3}\). Atmospheric pressure is \(1.0 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\)

The liquid is heated at its boiling point so that it completely vaporises. The increase in the internal energy of the substance during this process is \(17.6 \text{kJ}\). The final volume of the vapour is \(0.017 \text{m}^3\)
The substance in (b) has a specific latent heat of fusion \(L_{\mathrm{F}}\)
Suggest and explain whether \(L_{\mathrm{F}}\) is likely to be less than, the same as, or greater than the answer in (b)(iii)
State three of the basic assumptions of the kinetic theory of gases
Explain how molecular movement causes the pressure exerted by a gas
Fig. 4.1 shows the variation with thermodynamic temperature \(T\) of the mean-square speeds \(\langle c^2 \rangle\) for two gases X and Y
On Fig. 5.1, draw an arrow, from the centre of the sphere, to represent the direction of the resultant force acting on the sphere when it is in the position shown
State the amplitude of the oscillations
amplitude =   .........  \(m\)
Determine the angular frequency of the oscillations
angular frequency =   .........  \(rads^{-1}\)
Calculate the total energy of the oscillations
total energy =   .........  J
The mass of the sphere is \(0.15 \text{kg}\)
On Fig. 5.3, sketch the variation with \(x\) of the kinetic energy \(E_{\mathrm{K}}\) of the sphere
Fig. 5.1 shows a pendulum consisting of a metal sphere suspended by a thin string
(not to scale)
The sphere undergoes small oscillations about its equilibrium position. The oscillations may be considered to be simple harmonic
Fig. 5.2 shows the variation with time \(t\) of the displacement \(x\) of the sphere from its equilibrium position
State Coulomb's law
Fig. 6.1 shows an isolated hollow conducting sphere that is positively charged
On Fig. 6.1, draw field lines to represent the electric field outside the sphere
Determine the radius, in cm, of the sphere
Calculate the charge on the sphere
Suggest an explanation for the fact that the electric field inside the sphere is zero
Fig. 6.2 shows the variation of the electric field strength \(E\) with distance \(x\) from the centre of the sphere in **(b)**
Define the capacitance of a parallel-plate capacitor
On Fig. 7.1, sketch the variation of charge with p.d. for capacitor X as the p.d. increases from 0 to \(V.\)
Determine an expression, in terms of Q and \(V,\) for the work \(W\) done on capacitor X during the charging process. Explain your reasoning
An initially uncharged capacitor X, of capacitance C, is gradually charged so that the final potential difference (p.d.) between its plates is V and the final charge is Q
Complete Table 7.1 to show expressions, in terms of Q and \(V,\) for the final p.d.s across, and the final charges on, the two capacitors
Use the space below for any working that you need
State whether the total energy stored in the two capacitors is less than, the same as, or greater than the energy initially stored in capacitor X
Another capacitor Y is initially uncharged. The fully charged capacitor X in **(b)** is now connected to capacitor Y, as shown in Fig. 7.2
The capacitance of capacitor Y is 3C
State what is meant by the frequency of an alternating current
Show that the period of the alternating current is \(50 \text{ms}\)
On Fig. 8.1, sketch the variation of \(I\) with \(t\) between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 100 \text{ms}\)
Determine the root-mean-square (r.m.s.) current in the resistor
An alternating current \(I\) in a resistor of resistance \(680 \Omega\) varies with time \(t\) according to
where \(I\) is in A and \(t\) is in s
Use data from (b), including your answer in (b)(iii), to show by calculation that the mean power in the \(680\Omega\) resistor is half of the peak power
Explain what this observation shows about the nature of electrons
Determine an expression, in terms of \(m\), \(q\) and \(V\), for the momentum \(p\) of an electron in the beam
The p.d. through which the electrons are accelerated is now increased to a greater value
Describe and explain the effect of this change on the interference pattern observed
On Fig. 9.1, sketch the variation of \(p\) with \(\frac{1}{\lambda}\)
State the name of the quantity represented by the gradient of the line in Fig. 9.1
The electrons are now accelerated through different values of \(V\), resulting in pairs of corresponding values for \(p\) and the de Broglie wavelength \(\lambda\)
Electrons in a vacuum are accelerated from rest through a potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) to form a beam. The electrons each have mass \(m\) and charge \(q\)

The beam is incident on a graphite crystal that acts as a diffraction grating. After passing through the crystal, the beam reaches a fluorescent screen. An interference pattern is observed on this screen
State what is meant by random
State what is meant by spontaneous
State one piece of evidence for the random nature of decay
Radioactive decay is both random and spontaneous
Describe the differences between nuclear fission and nuclear fusion
Explain, with reference to the variation of binding energy per nucleon with nucleon number, why the processes of nuclear fission and nuclear fusion both result in a release of energy
